clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Functional Chewing Training on Tongue Thrust and Drooling in Children With Cerebral Palsy
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Functional Chewing Training on Tongue Thrust and Drooling in Children With Cerebral Palsy: A Randomised Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study examined the effect of Functional Chewing Training(FuCT) on tongue thrust and drooling in children with cerebral palsy.

detailed_description.textblock: Children were divided into two groups: The FuCT group and control group receiving classical oral motor exercises. Each group received training for 12 weeks. Oral motor assessment was performed. Chewing performance level was determined with the Karaduman Chewing Performance Scale(KCPS). Tongue thrust severity was evaluated with the Tongue Thrust Rating Scale(TTRS). The Drooling Severity and Frequency Scale(DSFS) was used to evaluate drooling severity and frequency. The evaluations were performed before and after treatment.

primary_outcome.description: Tongue thrust for each child is scored while they are feeding.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Drooling Severity and Frequency Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Parents were asked how often and in which severity experiencing drooling their children.

arm_group.description: Children with CP and have tongue thrust included this group.
Children with CP and have tongue thrust included this group.

intervention.description: FuCT; Family training Providing optimal sitting posture for children to support oral sensorimotor functions Positioning the food to the molar area during every meal to stimulate lateral and rotational tongue movements Massage of the upper and lower gums through the front teeth to molar area Chewing training to stimulate lateral and rotational tongue movements Gradually increasing the food consistency, for 12 weeks in 5 sets (1 set = 20 min) each day

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- diagnosed with cerebral palsy
- aged between 4-6 years
- fed by orally
- had tongue thrust
Exclusion Criteria:
- children who were unable the sitting position
